Boosting bidirectional sulfur conversion enabled by introducing boron-doped atoms and phosphorus vacancies in Ni2P for lithium-sulfur batteries Lin Peng Writing – original draft Validation Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a b Yu Bai Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization a b ⁎ Hang Li Investigation a b Meixiu Qu Validation Formal analysis a b Zhenhua Wang Resources b Kening Sun Supervision Resources b a Advanced Research Institute of Multidisciplinary Science, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China Advanced Research Institute of Multidisciplinary Science Beijing Institute of Technology Beijing 100081 China Advanced Research Institute of Multidisciplinary Science, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China b Beijing Key Laboratory of Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China Beijing Key Laboratory of Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Beijing Institute of Technology Beijing 100081 China Beijing Key Laboratory of Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The simultaneous introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies into Ni2P (Vp-B-Ni2P) regulates the electron structure and realizes the enhancement of the bidirectional sulfur conversion kinetics for Li-S batteries. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have gained great attention due to the high theoretical energy density and low cost, yet their further commercialization has been obstructed by the notorious shuttle effect and sluggish redox dynamics. Herein, we supply a strategy to optimize the electron structure of Ni2P by concurrently introducing B-doped atoms and P vacancies in Ni2P (Vp-B-Ni2P), thereby enhancing the bidirectional sulfur conversion. The study indicates that the simultaneous introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies in Ni2P causes the redistribution of electron around Ni atoms, bringing about the upward shift of d-band center of Ni atoms and effective d-p orbital hybridization between Ni atoms and sulfur species, thus strengthening the chemical anchoring for lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) as well as expediting the bidirectional conversion kinetics of sulfur species. Meanwhile, theoretical calculations reveal that the incorporation of B-doped atoms and P vacancies in Ni2P selectively promotes Li2S dissolution and nucleation processes. Thus, the Li-S batteries with Vp-B-Ni2P-separators present outstanding rate ability of 777 mA h g−1 at 5 C and high areal capacity of 8.03 mA h cm−2 under E/S of 5 μL mg−1 and sulfur loading of 7.20 mg cm−2. This work elucidates that introducing heteroatom and vacancy in metal phosphide collaboratively regulates the electron structure to accelerate bidirectional sulfur conversion. Keywords B-doped atoms P vacancies Nickel phosphide Bidirectional sulfur conversion Lithium-sulfur batteries 1 Introduction Under the urgent need of high energy storage systems, lithium-sulfur batteries have evoked great interesting due to their high theoretical energy density (2600 Wh kg−1) as well as abundant reserves and eco-friendliness of sulfur [1–5]. Nevertheless, the practical application is hampered by the rampant shuttle effect and sluggish redox kinetics, which are caused by the migration of soluble LiPSs and insulation characterization of sulfur and discharged products (Li2S2/Li2S) [6–8]. The aforementioned problems bring about inferior cycle stability and unsatisfactory rate performance. To overcome above challenges, carbon-based materials and transition metal compounds (such as oxides [9,10], sulfides [11,12], nitrides [13,14], phosphides [15,16], and borides [8,17]) have been applied as cathode host materials or separator modified layer to favor electron transport, inhibit shuttle effect, and accelerate redox conversion of LiPSs [18,19]. Notably, transition metal phosphides (TMPs) have gained research enthusiasm owing to their metallic nature and tunable morphology and structure [6]. In course of optimizing electrocatalytic activity of TMPs, heteroatom doping [20–23] and defect engineering [24,25] have drawn significant attention since they can adjust the electronic structure of TMPs, and thus enhance chemisorption and catalytic conversion for LiPSs. Particularly, the low electronegativity B atom with electron-deficient property is capable of adjusting the electronic density of metal atoms and coordinating with sulfur species [26–30]. Furthermore, the establishment of vacancies in TMPs can alter the energy band structure and optimize the charge distribution, which possesses the potential for regulating sulfur redox behaviors [31,32]. Although there have been some reports on the research of introducing heteroatoms or vacancies individually, the simultaneous introduction of both and an in-depth exploration of their inherent mechanisms on adsorption and catalytic conversion toward LiPSs still remain necessary. With aforementioned considerations, we simultaneously introduced B-doped atoms and P vacancies into Ni2P to regulate the electron structure, and investigated their influence on bidirectional conversion of sulfur species. The study reveals that the doped B atoms can form bonds with sulfur species in LiPSs to anchor active sulfur, while the introduced P vacancies create an abundance of unsaturated Ni active sites that can be applied as catalytic sites for sulfur conversion. In addition, the introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies induces the redistribution of electron around Ni atoms, which affects the d-band center of Ni atoms and d-p orbital hybridization between Ni sites and sulfur species, thus elevating the trapping LiPSs ability and promoting bidirectional LiPSs redox dynamics. Further theoretical calculations uncover that doping B atoms into Ni2P tends to stimulate the decomposition of Li2S, while the introduction of P vacancies is conducive to the reduction process of Li2S. The resultant Li-S batteries with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator manifest a splendid rate performance (777 mA h g−1 at 5 C) and superior areal capacity (8.03 mA h cm−2 under sulfur loading of 7.20 mg cm−2 and the electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio of 5 μL mg−1). This work unveils the potential of simultaneously introducing heteroatoms and vacancies in promoting the bidirectional conversion of sulfur species. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of flower-like Ni2P The flower-like Ni2P was prepared by solvothermal method and phosphorization process. Firstly, nickel nitrate (0.33 g) and hexamethylenetetramine (0.30 g) were dispersed in 24 mL N,N-dimethylformamide/ethanol solution (1:1, in volume) and the mixed solution was vigorously stirred for 0.3 h. Then, the above solution was placed into Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclaves and heated up to 150 °C for 6 h. The as-obtained precipitate was named as flower-like Ni-precursor after being washed with ethanol and dried overnight. For obtaining flower-like Ni2P, the flower-like Ni-precursor was annealed at 300 °C for 120 min (located at downstream) and the sodium hypophosphite monohydrate powder was used as phosphorus source (located at upstream). 2.2 Preparation of flower-like B-Ni2P The flower-like Ni-precursor (60 mg) and 0.1 M NaBH4 were poured into 30 mL ethanol solution and the obtained solution kept stirring for 0.5 h. After that, the mixed solution was transferred from beaker to an autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 60 min. Finally, the washed and dried product was transformed into B-Ni2P through the phosphating process. 2.3 Preparation of flower-like Vp-B-Ni2P Similarly, boric acid (132.5 mg) was used as boron source and the flower-like Ni-precursor (40 mg) was dispersed in 30 mL N,N-dimethylformamide solution under vigorous stirring. The above solution was put to a sealed autoclave which was kept at 180 °C for 6 h. After washing and drying, the Vp-B-Ni2P was obtained by phosphating the above product. 2.4 Materials characterization The scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Quanta 250) instrument and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2010F) instrument were applied to characterize and observe the morphology, size, and microstructure of Vp-B-Ni2P (B-Ni2P, and Ni2P). The phase structures of Vp-B-Ni2P (B-Ni2P and Ni2P) were investigated by Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffraction (XRD) machine. The surface chemical states of Vp-B-Ni2P (B-Ni2P and Ni2P) were evaluated by an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) instrument (ESCALAB-250XI). The contents of Ni and B elements were determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Agilent 725ES). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) data was obtained by Bruker EMXplus-6/1 Endor spectrometer. The ultraviolet-visible spectra (UV-vis, TU-1901) spectrometer was applied to study the Li2S6 adsorption effect. 2.5 Lithium polysulfide adsorption test First, 2.5 mL 1,2-dimethoxymethane (DME) and 2.5 mL 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) were added into a vial. Li2S (96.7 mg) and sulfur (334.0 mg) were dissolved in aforementioned solution, and then the solution was warmed to 80 °C for 24 h under vigorous stirring to prepare Li2S6 solution. The Vp-B-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P powders with same weight (20 mg) were separately put at vials containing 1.4 mmol L−1 Li2S6 solution. Finally, the color change of different vials was photographed after 24 h. 2.6 Assembly and measurement of Li2S6 symmetrical cell To prepare the electrode, 14.0 mg samples (Vp-B-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P) were dispersed into 1.0 mL ethanol solution and the above solution was added dropwise to carbon paper until the loading of materials reached 0.5 mg cm−2. Two identical electrodes with samples, a piece of Celgard 2325 separator, and 40 μL Li2S6 (0.42 mol L−1, DOL/DME as solvent, v/v = 1:1, containing 1.0 M LiTFSI) were used to assemble symmetrical cell. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) test was executed in the voltage range of −1–1 V at 200 mV s−1. 2.7 Li2S nucleation and dissolution tests First, we prepared Li2S8 solution, which was obtained by adding Li2S (87.5 mg) and sulfur powder (437.5 mg) in 5 mL DOL/DME (1:1 in volume). The same amount of Vp-B-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P powder (0.6 mg cm−2) was loaded on the carbon paper (a diameter of 12 mm), which is used as electrode. The 20 μL Li2S8 solution was used as active material and added in the above electrode. Lithium metal was employed as counter electrode and put in 20 μL electrolyte (without Li2S8). The fabricated cells were discharged to 2.10 V under the constant current condition of 0.112 mA, and then discharged at the constant voltage of 2.09 V to induce the Li2S nucleation. For the measurement of Li2S dissociation, the same batteries as those in the Li2S nucleation test were firstly discharged to 1.7 V at a constant current (the current was set to 0.112 mA) to form Li2S, and then potentiostatically charged at 2.4 V for the dissolution of Li2S until the current decreased below 0.01 mA. 2.8 Electrochemical measurement To prepare the cathode, 98 mg sulfur, 42 mg carbon nanotube (CNT), 40 mg super P, and 20 mg polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) were mixed in 1.2 mL N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solution, and then the above slurry was covered on the commercial carbon paper (12 mm in diameter). The sulfur loading is 1.5–7.2 mg cm−2. For preparing modified separators, the 60 mg synthetic samples (Vp-B-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P), 30 mg CNT, and 10 mg PVDF were dispersed in 1000 μL NMP solution to obtain even slurry, then loaded on Celgard 2325. The diameter of separator was 19 mm and the mass loading of materials is 0.40 mg cm−2. DOL/DME solution including 1.0 M LiTFSI and 2.0 wt% LiNO3 was served as the electrolyte. The S/CNT cathode, the lithium metal anode, and different modified separators were used to assemble 2025-type coin cells under the content of H2O and O2 < 0.1 ppm in argon-filled glove box. In addition, 4 cm × 4 cm S/CNT cathode, 5 cm × 5 cm lithium foil with a thickness of 100 μm, and 5.5 cm × 5.5 cm Vp-B-Ni2P-separator were applied to fabricate the pouch cell. The energy density of the pouch cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator without packages is 115.6 Wh kg−1. The CV curves were gained by CHI-760E electrochemical system, with the potential range of 1.6–2.8 V. The electrochemistry performance which includes cycling (0.05, 0.1, 2, and 5 C) and rate performance (0.2–5 C) was tried out by Neware battery testing system. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were executed on Parstat 2273 advanced electrochemical system with the amplitude being 5 mV and the frequency range being 10−1–105 Hz. To measure shuttle current, the cells with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator, B-Ni2P-separator, Ni2P-separator, and CNT-separator using LiNO3-free electrolyte were firstly discharged and then charged at 0.1 C. Subsequently, the cells were discharged to 2.38 V at 0.1 C and kept in potentiostatic program. Finally, the stable-state current was collected as shuttle current. 2.9 Theoretical calculations Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were investigated by Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP). We have used the projected augmented wave (PAW) method and Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional to depict the ion-electron interaction and exchange-correlation energy, respectively. The Brillouin zone was established as 2 × 2 × 1 k-point mesh and 20 Å of vacuum space in a perpendicular direction was inserted on the model surface. In addition, the plane-wave cut-off energy was designated as 400 eV and the convergence tolerances of maximum force and energy were 0.05 eV Å−1 and 10−4 eV. The energy barriers of Li+ diffusion and Li2S decomposition were simulated by the climbing image nudged elastic band method with convergence criterion of 0.05 eV Å−1. In addition, the binding energies (E b) were calculated as follow. (1) E b = E ( L i x S y / s l a b ) - E L i x S y - E s l a b where E ( L i x S y / s l a b ) , E L i x S y , and E s l a b were the total energy of the adsorbate on the substrate, the energy of isolated LiPSs, and the energy of substrate, respectively. The values of Gibbs free energy changes (ΔG) for sulfur reduction processes can be calculated as follow [2,33]. (2) Δ G L i 2 S 8 ∗ = G L i 2 S 8 ∗ - G S 8 ∗ - 2 G L i (3) Δ G L i 2 S 6 ∗ = G L i 2 S 6 ∗ + 1 4 G S 8 - G L i 2 S 8 ∗ (4) Δ G L i 2 S 4 ∗ = G L i 2 S 4 ∗ + 1 4 G S 8 - G L i 2 S 6 ∗ (5) Δ G L i 2 S 2 ∗ = G L i 2 S 2 ∗ + 1 4 G S 8 - G L i 2 S 4 ∗ (6) Δ G L i 2 S ∗ = G L i 2 S ∗ + 1 8 G S 8 - G L i 2 S 2 ∗ The values of Gibbs free energy can be attained as follow. (7) G = E b + E Z P E - T S = E b + G T where E Z P E , T, and S stand for zero-point energy, temperature, and entropy, respectively. G T can be gained after frequency analysis of adsorbate on the substrate at 298.15 K by VASPKIT code. 3 Results and discussion The synthesis route of flower-like Vp-B-Ni2P is exhibited in Fig. 1 (a). Specifically, the flower-like Ni-precursor was firstly fabricated by the solvothermal method by adding nickel nitrate and hexamethylenetetramine in a mixture solution of ethanol and N, N-dimethylformamide. Subsequently, Ni-precursor and boric acid (served as boron source) were heated at 180 °C for 6 h and then the above product was phosphatized under phosphine atmosphere to gain Vp-B-Ni2P. The morphology of the obtained samples was investigated by SEM and TEM. Vp-B-Ni2P (Fig. 1b and c) demonstrates a flower-like morphology with the diameter of 1 μm and the flower-like structure is composed of interconnected nanosheets (Fig. 1d). Similarly, Ni2P (Figs. S1a and S2a) and B-Ni2P (Figs. S1b and S2b) inherit the flower-like structure. Such a flower-like structure is beneficial to the exposure of active sites for anchoring and catalytic conversion of sulfur species. The element mappings of Vp-B-Ni2P (Fig. S3) and B-Ni2P (Fig. S4) illustrate the uniform distribution of Ni, P, O, and B elements, demonstrating the successful introduction of B atoms. In addition, the identical content of B element in Vp-B-Ni2P and B-Ni2P can be revealed by the ICP-OES results (Table S1). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of Vp-B-Ni2P presents a lattice spacing of 0.203 nm (Fig. 1e), which is ascribed to (201) lattice facet of hexagonal Ni2P. Nevertheless, the lattice fringes of Vp-B-Ni2P become discontinuous compared with those of Ni2P and B-Ni2P (Fig. S5), which can be attributed to the existence of defects due to the formation of phosphorus vacancies. Additionally, the XRD patterns of Vp-B-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P (Fig. 1f) display identical diffraction peaks as hexagonal Ni2P phase (JCPDF 03-0953), indicating that the introduction of B atoms and P vacancies does not cause phase transformation. The EPR measurement is applied to explore the defects characteristics in Vp-B-Ni2P (Fig. 1g). In contrast to the Ni2P and B-Ni2P, a strong EPR signal of Vp-B-Ni2P near the g-value of 2.004 indicates the formation of more unpaired electrons, which is attributed to the existence of P vacancies [23,34]. The existence of P vacancies can cause the exposure of unsaturated Ni atoms, which can function as catalytic active sites to promote sulfur conversion. To investigate the chemical states and elemental compositions of Vp-B-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P, XPS measurements were carried out. All XPS spectra data is presented in Table S2. For Ni2P, the Ni 2p high-resolution XPS spectrum as illustrated in Fig. 2 (a) includes two spin-orbit peaks of Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2. Specifically, Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2 can be deconvoluted into Ni–P (853.1 and 870.3 eV), Ni–O (856.7 and 874.8 eV), and Ni satellite peaks (861.9 and 880.1 eV), respectively. Compared with the Ni2P, a negative shift of Ni 2p peaks in B-Ni2P can be observed, indicating the increased electron density around Ni atoms, which could be attributed to the introduction of B atoms with weak electron-withdrawing ability [35]. As compared with B-Ni2P, the binding energies of Ni 2p peaks for Vp-B-Ni2P shift negatively, illustrating the enhanced electron density of Ni atoms, which is ascribed to the introduction of phosphorus vacancies into B-Ni2P. The change of charge density indicates the formation of unsaturated coordination Ni atoms, which can act as adsorption and catalytic sites to enhance the chemisorption and catalytic conversion of LiPSs [32,36,37]. Additionally, the B 1s XPS spectra of Vp-B-Ni2P and B-Ni2P are presented in Fig. 2(b). B 1s XPS spectrum is divided into B–Ni peak located at low binding energy and B–O peak situated at high binding energy. Specifically, the generation of B–O bond is attributed to the inevitable surface oxidation [38]. B–Ni peaks in B-Ni2P and Vp-B-Ni2P appeared at 187.2 and 187.1 eV, respectively, indicating the successful introduction of B atoms into B-Ni2P and Vp-B-Ni2P. To probe the anchoring ability of Vp-B-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P for LiPSs, the Li2S6 visualization adsorption tests were conducted (Fig. 2c). The equivalent mass of three samples was added into the Li2S6 solution, respectively. Compared with Ni2P, the yellow color of Li2S6 solution with B-Ni2P becomes lighter while the Li2S6 solution containing Vp-B-Ni2P almost turns transparent, indicating the enhanced affinity ability for LiPSs by introducing B-doped atoms and P vacancies. Additionally, the UV-vis absorbance spectra unveil that the Li2S6 solution with Vp-B-Ni2P exhibits the lowest intensity of adsorption peak, indicating the strongest adsorption ability of Vp-B-Ni2P toward LiPSs. Subsequently, the chemical interaction between samples (Vp-B-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P) and LiPSs was probed by XPS analysis. The binding energies corresponding to each peak are presented in Table S3. After the chemisorption of Li2S6, the peaks in Ni 2p XPS spectra of three samples as presented in Fig. 2(d) shift negatively, which is on account of the electron transfer from Li2S6 to Ni atoms. Specifically, Ni 2p peaks of B-Ni2P-Li2S6 are more obvious for negative shift than those of Ni2P-Li2S6, testifying the improved chemical trapping ability due to doped B atoms in Ni2P. Notably, the largest negative shift of Ni 2p peaks is exhibited in Vp-B-Ni2P-Li2S6, indicating that the interaction between Li2S6 and unsaturated Ni atoms is significantly reinforced by introducing B-doped atoms and P vacancies. In addition, B 1s peaks of B-Ni2P-Li2S6 and Vp-B-Ni2P-Li2S6 also shift to lower binding energies (Fig. S6), which is attributed to the increase in electron density due to the coordination of B and S [29,30]. To evaluate the ability of inhibiting shuttle effect, the polysulfides permeation tests across different modified separators were performed. The cross-sectional SEM image of Vp-B-Ni2P-separator detects that the thickness of coating layer is approximately 10 μm (Fig. S7). In H-shaped glass container (Fig. S8), the left container is 14 mM Li2S6 solution and the right container contains DOL/DME solvent (v/v = 1/1). After resting for 6 h, the color change of solvent with Ni2P-separator is more obvious (from colorless to yellow). On the contrary, a slight color change of the solvent is displayed for B-Ni2P-separator and almost no color variation is shown for Vp-B-Ni2P-separator. This consequence reveals that the ability of suppressing LiPSs diffusion is reinforced by the coexistence of B atoms and P vacancies. To uncover the electrocatalytic ability for soluble LiPSs conversion, the CV measurements on symmetric cells with Vp-B-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P were implemented as presented in Fig. 3 (a). Comparing with the Ni2P symmetric cell, the redox current obviously increases in Vp-B-Ni2P and B-Ni2P symmetric cells. Notably, Vp-B-Ni2P symmetric cell presents the highest current response, elucidating the promoted redox conversion for LiPSs owing to the introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies. In addition to the catalytic ability for soluble LiPSs conversion, the catalytic function of different samples for precipitation and dissolution of solid phase Li2S also is essential for enhancing the electrochemical performance. Therefore, the Li2S nucleation and dissolution measurements were implemented. The i-t curves are detected and the nucleation/dissolution capacity of Li2S is calculated. For Li2S deposition process (Fig. 3b), the Vp-B-Ni2P based cells deliver the highest precipitated capacity of Li2S and the shortest current response (340.4 mA h g−1, 3520 s) compared with B-Ni2P (232.9 mA h g−1, 3675 s) and Ni2P (157.1 mA h g−1, 5964 s) based cells, revealing that the introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies in Ni2P can synergistically promote Li2S precipitation. In Li2S dissolution process (Fig. 3c), the largest dissolution capacity and the quickest peak current response (710.4 mA h g−1, 1200 s) on Vp-B-Ni2P based cell can be observed, suggesting that Vp-B-Ni2P can significantly facilitate the conversion from Li2S to soluble LiPSs. The excellent Li2S nucleation and dissolution ability validate that Vp-B-Ni2P can bidirectionally facilitate the conversion between LiPSs and Li2S [39], thus improving sulfur conversion kinetics. To further investigate the influence of introducing B-doped atoms and P vacancies for Li-S cells, the electrochemical performance measurements were implemented in the cells with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator, B-Ni2P-separator, Ni2P-separator, and CNT-separator. The strengthened LiPSs conversion kinetics on Vp-B-Ni2P-separator is verified by the CV tests (Fig. 3d). Specifically, the two peaks centered at 2.3 and 2.0 V are credited to the reduction steps of S8 to soluble LiPSs and then to Li2S, respectively. Besides, the peaks situated 2.3 and 2.4 V belong to the oxidation process of Li2S to LiPSs and subsequently to S8. The CV curves with scan rates of 0.1–0.5 mV s−1 are illustrated in Fig. S9. The cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator displays the largest peak current value, the smallest polarization, and the lowest Tafel slopes (Fig. S10) compared with the cells with B-Ni2P-separator, Ni2P-separator, and CNT-separator, elucidating the promoted LiPSs redox kinetics due to the presence of B-doped atoms and P vacancies. Subsequently, Li-ion diffusion coefficient ( D L i + ) is calculated by the Randles-Sevick equation due to the linear relationship between redox peak current and the square root of the scan rate [40,41]. The fitted curves and calculated D L i + are listed in Fig. 3(e–g) and Table S4, respectively. The largest value of D L i + of A, C1, and C2 peaks can be obtained by the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator, revealing the accelerated Li-ion diffusion by introducing B-doped atoms and P vacancies. The rate performance is an important parameter to evaluate the electrochemical performance. Compared with the batteries with B-Ni2P-separator, Ni2P-separator, and CNT-separator, the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator manifests the highest specific capacities at rates of 0.2–5 C (Fig. 4 a). Specifically, the initial specific capacity of 1492 mA h g−1 is achieved for the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator at 0.2 C, which reaches 89.0% of theoretical specific capacity, demonstrating the sufficient utilization of active sulfur species. Even under the high rates of 3 and 5 C, the high capacities of 906 and 777 mA h g−1 are accomplished for the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator, respectively. When the rate recovers from 5 to 2 C, the capacity of the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator restores to 994 mA h g−1 (96.2% of the initial capacity), manifesting the superior electrochemical reversibility. The excellent rate performance testifies the promoted conversion kinetics and anchoring ability toward LiPSs due to the coexistence of B-doped atoms and P vacancies in Ni2P. The polarization of different cells between 0.2 and 5 C is delivered in Fig. 4(b), which is calculated by the corresponding charge/discharge profiles (Fig. S11). The lowest polarization potential of the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator is achieved at all rates, manifesting the favorable conversion kinetics of sulfur. The long-term cycling performance of the batteries with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator, B-Ni2P-separator, Ni2P-separator, and CNT-separator is estimated at 2 C (Fig. 4c) and the corresponding charge-discharge profiles are presented in Fig. S12. The cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator exhibits the original capacity of 1053 mA h g−1, which is higher than that of the cells with B-Ni2P-separator (984 mA h g−1), Ni2P-separator (877 mA h g−1), and CNT-separator (738 mA h g−1). A capacity of 683 mA h g−1 is obtained for the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator after 500 cycles of discharge and charge, which exhibits the lowest capacity decay rate of 0.07% per cycle contrasted with the cells with B-Ni2P-separator (0.10%), Ni2P-separator (0.11%), and CNT-separator (0.12% after 300 cycles). To conduct further research on the cycle stability of the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator at a high rate, the cycling performance test is implemented at 5 C as presented in Fig. 4(d) and the corresponding charge-discharge profile is presented in Fig. S13. The cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator achieves an initial capacity of 711 mA h g−1 and remains the capacity of 482 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles, which delivers a low-capacity decay rate of 0.063%. EIS measurements were implemented to explore the causation of enhanced redox kinetics. The EIS plots are presented in Fig. 4(e) and Fig. S14 (the insert image is corresponding equivalent circuits) and the fitted results are enumerated in Table S5. Compared with the cell with B-Ni2P-separator, Ni2P-separator, and CNT-separator, the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator possesses the lowest charge-transfer resistance (R ct) before and after cycles, demonstrating the rapid charge transfer on Vp-B-Ni2P. After cycling, the interface contact resistance (R g) appears at high frequency region, which is attributed to the formation of insoluble Li2S/Li2S2 layer. The smallest R g is achieved by the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator compared with other cells, indicating the promoted uniform deposition of Li2S2/Li2S due to the introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies. The shuttle current measurement was conducted to evaluate the inhibition effect of Vp-B-Ni2P-separator, B-Ni2P-separator, Ni2P-separator, and CNT-separator on the shuttle effect (Fig. S15). The cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator exhibits the smallest current shuttle compared with other cells, indicating the enhanced ability to capture lithium polysulfide due to the introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies. Furthermore, SEM images of the lithium anode of different cells and corresponding elemental mapping of oxygen and sulfur after cycling are illustrated in Fig. S16. The atomic percentage on the lithium anode surface is shown in Table S6 and the S/O atoms ratio in the cells with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator, B-Ni2P-separator, Ni2P-separator, and CNT-separator is 0.033:1, 0.042:1, 0.064:1, and 0.075, respectively. The results indicate that a smoother surface of Li anode and less deposition of sulfur element can be detected in the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator, elucidating that Vp-B-Ni2P can hinder the shuttle of LiPSs and mitigate the corrosion of Li metal. To meet the demand of high-energy-density lithium-sulfur battery, the cycling performance of the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator at high sulfur loading and lean electrolyte is carried out. When the E/S is 7 μL mg−1 (Fig. S17), the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator with sulfur loading of 2.80, 3.45, and 4.95 mg cm−2 exhibits the initial areal capacity of 3.86, 3.93, and 5.33 mA h cm−2 at 0.1 C, respectively, and the corresponding charge-discharge curves are displayed in Fig. S18. When further decreasing the amount of electrolyte used (E/S of 5 μL mg−1) and increasing sulfur loading (7.20 mg cm−2), a high initial areal capacity of 8.03 mA h cm−2 (1120 mA h g−1) is attained for the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator, which remains 5.06 mA h cm−2 (706 mA h g−1) after 40 cycles at 0.05 C (Fig. 4f), and the corresponding charge-discharge curves are provided in Fig. S19. Fig. 4(g) exhibits the performance comparison between our work and other researches, demonstrating the superior areal capacity of the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator in the case of high sulfur loading and lean electrolyte. Furthermore, the pouch cell fabricated with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator powers a light-emitting diode (LED) panel (inset in Fig. 4h) and delivers a capacity of 858 mA h g−1 (4.83 mA h cm−2) with the sulfur loading of 5.63 mg cm−2 at 0.1 C. The corresponding charge-discharge profile exhibits the obvious charging and discharging platform (Fig. S20). After 100 cycles, a capacity of 700 mA h g−1 (3.94 mA h cm−2) can be retained (Fig. 4h), which exhibits a capacity retention of 81.6%. The performance comparison in Li-S pouch cells between our results and other articles is shown in Table S7. The pouch cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator delivers higher area capacity, which reveals the excellent electrochemical performance of the cells with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator. Such a superior electrochemical performance implies the potential of Vp-B-Ni2P to practical Li-S batteries. The excellent electrochemical performance of the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator is related with the facilitated trapping LiPSs ability and promoted bidirectional conversion of LiPSs due to the coexistence of B-doped atoms and P vacancies (Fig. 4i). In situ Raman spectra were conducted to evaluate the ability of preventing shuttle effect for different modified separator. For the cell with Ni2P-separator (Fig. 5 a–c), the peaks located at 472, 325/398, and 455 cm−1 are ascribed to the characteristic peak of S8/S8 2−, S6 2−/S4 2−, and S4 2−/S3 2−, respectively [42,43]. During discharge and charge processes, the obvious LiPSs signal can be detected, manifesting the formation of an irreversible and severe LiPSs shuttling. In contrast, the weak peaks of S8/S8 2−, S6 2−/S4 2−, and S4 2−/S3 2− can be observed in the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator at the initial discharge process (Fig. 5d–f). During the subsequent charging process, the characteristic peaks of LiPSs can scarcely be detected. The above result reveals the enhanced anchoring ability toward LiPSs and the facilitated bidirectional conversion of Li2S due to the introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies, resulting in effectively alleviating LiPSs shuttling. DFT simulations were carried out to uncover the role of the introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies in adsorption ability and catalytic activity in Li-S chemistry. To start with, Ni2P, B-Ni2P, Vp-Ni2P, and Vp-B-Ni2P models are built and optimized. The three-dimensional (3D) charge-density difference plots (Fig. S21) display the yellow and cyan regions, which represent electron accumulation and depletion, respectively. Obviously, the redistribution of charge density can be observed after introducing B-doped atoms and P vacancies in Ni2P. The two-dimensional (2D) charge density difference plots also clearly show that the charge accumulation around Ni atoms in Vp-B-Ni2P is more obvious than that in Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Vp-Ni2P (Fig. S22), which corresponds with the XPS analysis. The enhanced charge density around Ni atoms may influence its d-band centers. The d-band center theory indicates that the upward shift of d-band center of metal toward the Fermi level will elevate the antibonding orbital between metal and adsorbed molecules above Fermi level, resulting in fewer electrons filling the antibonding orbital, and thus the interaction with adsorbed molecules is enhanced [44,45]. Therefore, we further calculate the partial density of states (DOS) for Ni 3d orbitals (Fig. 6 a) and obtain the value of d-band center. The d-band center of Vp-B-Ni2P (−1.39 eV) is closer to Fermi level compared with Vp-Ni2P (−1.41 eV), B-Ni2P (−1.43 eV), and Ni2P (−1.44 eV), indicating relatively stronger interaction between Vp-B-Ni2P and LiPSs [46,47]. The shift of d-band center of Ni atoms may also affect the hybridization strength of the d-p orbitals between Ni atoms and sulfur species, thus impacting the chemsorption and catalytic conversion ability for LiPSs. The projected crystal orbital Hamilton population method (pCOHP) can reveal bonding and antibonding characteristics between Ni atoms and S atoms. The positive value of −pCOHP stands for bonding states, while the negative values are attributed to antibonding states [48]. Thus, the integrated-COHP (iCOHP) below the fermi level can evaluate the bonding strength of Ni–S, which also reflects the strength of d-p orbital hybridization between Ni atoms and sulfur atoms [49,50] (Fig. 6c). The more negative iCOHP attained by Vp-B-Ni2P (−1.89 eV) illustrates a more effective d-p orbital hybridization between Ni atoms and sulfur atoms, which can improve the strength of Ni–S bonds and interface electronic transfer, thus improving the anchoring effect toward LiPSs and sulfur conversion kinetics. Subsequently, we optimize the configurations of S8/LiPSs on the Vp-B-Ni2P, Vp-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P surface to investigate the adsorption behaviors (Figs. S23–S26). The binding energies between different samples and S8/LiPSs are calculated as presented in Fig. 6(d). The adsorption energies of S8/LiPSs on the surface of Vp-Ni2P and B-Ni2P are higher than those on the surface of Ni2P, uncovering the enhanced affinity for LiPSs by introducing the B-doped atoms or P vacancies. Significantly, Vp-B-Ni2P delivers the highest binding energy toward various sulfur species, indicating that the simultaneous introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies can significantly elevate the anchoring ability of LiPSs, which is in accord with the result of adsorption tests. The charge density difference plots as illustrated in Fig. S27 indicate the charge transfer between different substrates (Vp-B-Ni2P, Vp-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P) and Li2S6/Li2S4/Li2S and reveal that Vp-B-Ni2P anchor LiPSs by forming Ni–S, P–Li, and B–S bonds. To further investigate the mechanism of catalytic enhancement for LiPSs conversion, the Gibbs free energies of sulfur reduction reactions on the surfaces of Vp-B-Ni2P, Vp-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P were calculated (Fig. 6e). During the conversion from S8* to Li2S6*, the values of Gibbs free energy changes (ΔG) are negative, indicating that this process is spontaneous. Subsequently, the ΔG values are positive during the transformation from Li2S6* to Li2S*, revealing that these processes are all unspontaneous [2]. Especially, the ΔG value for the conversion from Li2S2* to Li2S* is the highest and thus this step is usually considered as rate-determining step during the whole discharge process [51,52]. In contrast to Ni2P, the decreased ΔG values in the Li2S2*/Li2S* process are achieved by B-Ni2P and Vp-Ni2P, implying that the respective introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies are thermodynamically beneficial to promoting the conversion from Li2S2 to Li2S. Especially, the even lower ΔG value of Vp-Ni2P is presented compared with B-Ni2P, signifying that the introduction of P vacancies mainly plays a role in promoting the Li2S reduction. Therefore, Vp-B-Ni2P exhibits the smallest ΔG value due to the simultaneous introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies, revealing the promoted Li2S nucleation. Since the Li2S decomposition process is regarded as rate-limiting steps in charging process, the energy barriers of Li2S dissociation and corresponding pathways (from Li2S to LiS + Li) on the surface of Vp-B-Ni2P, Vp-Ni2P, B-Ni2P, and Ni2P are evaluated (Fig. 6f–i). Relative to Ni2P (0.66 eV), the dissociation energy barriers of Li2S on both B-Ni2P (0.15 eV) and Vp-Ni2P (0.34 eV) are decreased, clarifying that the respective incorporation of B-doped atoms and P vacancies is favorable for the Li2S decomposition. Particularly, the energy barrier of Li2S on B-Ni2P is lower compared with Vp-Ni2P, indicating that doping B atoms in Ni2P acts as a main role in facilitating the conversion from Li2S to polysulfides. Based on the introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies, the dissolution barrier for Li2S on the surface of Vp-B-Ni2P (0.12 eV) is the lowest among others, revealing that Vp-B-Ni2P is beneficial to promoting the Li2S dissolution. The diffusion ability of Li+ on the material surface also influences the redox reaction kinetics of LiPSs (Fig. 6j–m). The diffusion energy barrier of Li+ on the surface of Vp-B-Ni2P (0.26 eV) is lower than that on the surface of Vp-Ni2P (0.39 eV), B-Ni2P (0.41 eV), and Ni2P (0.44 eV), indicating the facilitated Li+ diffusion by simultaneous introducing B-doped atoms and P vacancies, which is conducive to the redox process of sulfur species. The above results testify that the simultaneous introduction of B atom and P vacancy in Ni2P can strengthen the affinity to LiPSs and promote bidirectional Li2S conversion kinetics. 4 Conclusions In summary, we provide a strategy to regulate electron structure of Ni2P through concurrently implanting B-doped atoms and P vacancies, and realize the enhancement of the bidirectional sulfur conversion kinetics for Li-S batteries. The incorporation of B-doped atoms and P vacancies induces the alteration of the charge density surrounding Ni active sites, resulting in the upward shift of d-band center of Ni atoms and effective d-p orbital hybridization between Ni atoms and sulfur species. Theoretical calculations uncover that the B-doped atoms can effectively decrease the energy barriers of Li2S decomposition, thereby stimulating the decomposition of Li2S. The introduction of P vacancies is thermodynamically favorable for the Li2S reduction, thus facilitating the Li2S nucleation. In addition, the introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies promotes the chemical adsorption capacity for LiPSs and accelerates the diffusion of Li+. As a result, the cell with Vp-B-Ni2P-separator delivers an outstanding rate performance of 777 mA h g−1 at 5 C and a high areal capacity of 8.03 mA h cm−2 under the condition of high sulfur loading (7.20 mg cm−2) and lean electrolyte (E/S of 5 μL mg−1). Additionally, the Li-S pouch cell fabricated with the Vp-B-Ni2P-separator achieves the capacity of 858 mA h g−1 with sulfur loading of 5.63 mg cm−2 and remains a stable cycle for 100 cycles. This work reveals the role of introducing heteroatom and vacancy in metal phosphide in promoting the bidirectional sulfur conversion, providing a strategy for developing high-performance Li-S batteries by optimizing electron structure of electrocatalyst. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have gained great attention due to the high theoretical energy density and low cost, yet their further commercialization has been obstructed by the notorious shuttle effect and sluggish redox dynamics. Herein, we supply a strategy to optimize the electron structure of Ni2P by concurrently introducing B-doped atoms and P vacancies in Ni2P (Vp-B-Ni2P), thereby enhancing the bidirectional sulfur conversion. The study indicates that the simultaneous introduction of B-doped atoms and P vacancies in Ni2P causes the redistribution of electron around Ni atoms, bringing about the upward shift of d-band center of Ni atoms and effective d-p orbital hybridization between Ni atoms and sulfur species, thus strengthening the chemical anchoring for lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) as well as expediting the bidirectional conversion kinetics of sulfur species. Meanwhile, theoretical calculations reveal that the incorporation of B-doped atoms and P vacancies in Ni2P selectively promotes Li2S dissolution and nucleation processes. Thus, the Li-S batteries with Vp-B-Ni2P-separators present outstanding rate ability of 777 mA h g−1 at 5 C and high areal capacity of 8.03 mA h cm−2 under E/S of 5 μL mg−1 and sulfur loading of 7.20 mg cm−2. This work elucidates that introducing heteroatom and vacancy in metal phosphide collaboratively regulates the electron structure to accelerate bidirectional sulfur conversion.
